question: As an employer, I need to understand the definition of 'Candidate for Employment' as stated in the legal documents. Can you provide me with the specific criteria that determine whether someone is considered a candidate for employment?
reference_answer: A 'Candidate for Employment' refers to a person who has applied for a specific employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the employer or employment agency.
reference_context:
Document 4: 1 
 
New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection 
 
Notice of Adoption of Final Rule 
 
Pursuant to the authority vested in the Commissioner of the Department of Consumer and Worker Protection by 
Sections 1043 and 2203(f) of the New York City Charter and Section 20-104(b) of the New York City 
Administrative Code, and in accordance with the requirements of Section 1043 of the New York City Charter, 
the Department amends Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York.  
 
An initial version of this rule was proposed and published on September 23, 2022. A public hearing was held on 
November 4, 2022, and comments regarding the rule were received. DCWP proposed a second version of this 
rule on December 23, 2022. A public hearing was held on January 23, 2023, and comments regarding the rule 
were received.  
 
Statement of Basis and Purpose 
 
The Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (“DCWP” or “Department”) is adding rules to implement 
new legislation regarding automated employment decision tools (“AEDT”). Local Law 144 of 2021 prohibits 
employers and employment agencies from using an automated employment decision tool unless the tool has 
been subject to a bias audit within one year of the use of the tool, information about the bias audit is publicly 
available, and certain notices have been provided to employees or job candidates.   
 
These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law.

Document 7: 3 
 
Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.  
 
Historical data.

agent_answer: According to the legal documents, a "Candidate for Employment" is defined as a person who has applied for a specific employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the employer or employment agency. This means that to be considered a candidate, an individual must actively apply for a job and provide the required application materials as specified by the employer.

question: I'm an employer in New York City and want to understand the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool. Can you explain the definition of an automated employment decision tool and the conditions that need to be met before using it?
reference_answer: An automated employment decision tool is defined as any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. Before using an automated employment decision tool in New York City, the following conditions must be met: 1. The tool must have undergone a bias audit within one year prior to its use. 2. A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit and the distribution date of the tool must be publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website. 3. Employers or employmnet agencies must notify candidates or employees residing in the city at least 10 business days before using the tool.
reference_context:
Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

metadata: {'question_type': 'complex_situational', 'seed_document_id': 0, 'topic': 'Requirements'}
agent_answer:
Certainly! In New York City, an **Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT)** is defined as any computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to issue simplified outputs (like scores, classifications, or recommendations) that substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making in employment decisions.

### Conditions for Using an AEDT:

1. **Bias Audit Requirement**:
   - The AEDT must have undergone a **bias audit** within one year prior to its use. This audit assesses the tool's impact on various demographic categories (e.g., race, ethnicity, sex).

2. **Public Disclosure**:
   - A summary of the results from the most recent bias audit, along with the **distribution date** (the date the employer began using the AEDT), must be made publicly available on the employer's or employment agency's website before using the tool.

3. **Notification to Candidates**:
   - Employers must notify candidates or employees that an AEDT will be used in their assessment. This notice must be provided at least **ten business days** before the tool is used.
   - The notice should include:
     - Information that an AEDT will be used.
     - The job qualifications and characteristics that the AEDT will assess.
     - If not disclosed on the website, details about the type of data used by the AEDT.

### Summary:
Before using an AEDT, ensure it has been audited for bias, that the audit results are publicly available, and that candidates are properly notified about the use of the tool and its assessment criteria.

question: In the context of a bias audit, what is the definition of 'test data' and when can it be used?
reference_answer: 'Test data' refers to data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data.
reference_context:
Document 18: (a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of results of the 
bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was 
generated and obtained.  
 
Example 1: An employer is planning to use an AEDT for the first time. The employer may rely on a bias 
audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or employment agencies, or on a bias audit 
conducted using test data.

Document 19: 9 
 
Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency

to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

agent_answer:
In the context of a bias audit, "test data" refers to data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. It can be utilized when there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit employs test data, it must include a summary of the results explaining why historical data was not used and describe how the test data was generated and obtained. 

This allows employers or employment agencies to rely on a bias audit using test data, particularly when they are using an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) for the first time or when they do not have enough historical data from their own use of the AEDT.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides an overly detailed explanation and includes additional context about when test data can be used, which is not part of the ground truth definition.

question: As an employer conducting a bias audit, I want to know the threshold for excluding a category from impact ratio calculations. Can you clarify what percentage of data a category must represent to be excluded?
reference_answer: An independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio.
reference_context:
Document 16: (d) Notwithstanding the requirements of paragraphs (2) and (3) of subdivision (b) and paragraphs (3) and 
(4) of subdivision (c), an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of 
the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a 
category is excluded, the summary of results must include the independent auditor’s justification for the 
exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded 
category.

ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.

agent_answer:
### Simplified Definition of Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT)

An **Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT)** is a system that uses technology—like machine learning or data analytics—to help make decisions about hiring or promotions. It generates outputs such as scores or classifications that can significantly influence who gets hired or promoted.

### Impact on Employment Decisions

AEDTs can streamline the hiring process by quickly evaluating candidates based on specific criteria. However, they also raise concerns about fairness and bias, as they can inadvertently disadvantage certain groups if not properly audited.

### Requirements for Using AEDTs in New York City

1. **Bias Audit**: 
   - Before using an AEDT, employers must conduct a **bias audit** within the last year. This audit assesses whether the tool has a disparate impact on different demographic groups.

2. **Public Disclosure**: 
   - Employers must make a summary of the most recent bias audit results publicly available on their website, along with the date the tool was distributed.

3. **Notification to Candidates**: 
   - Employers must notify candidates or employees at least **10 business days** before using an AEDT. This notification should include:
     - A statement that an AEDT will be used.
     - The job qualifications and characteristics that the tool will assess.
     - If not disclosed on the website, information about the type of data the tool uses.

4. **Alternative Selection Process**: 
   - Candidates must be allowed to request an alternative selection process or accommodation if they prefer not to be evaluated by the AEDT.

These requirements aim to ensure transparency and fairness in the use of technology in employment decisions, helping to mitigate potential biases.
correctness_reason: The agent's definition of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) is overly simplified and does not fully capture the comprehensive definition provided in the ground truth, which includes specific details about the computational processes involved.

question: I'm an employer in New York City and want to understand the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool. Could you explain what constitutes an automated employment decision tool and the conditions that must be met for its use?
reference_answer: An automated employment decision tool is any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. It does not include tools that do not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making processes and that do not materially impact natural persons.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

Document 2: The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.

agent_answer:
In New York City, an **Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT)** is defined as any computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to issue simplified outputs (like scores, classifications, or recommendations) that substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making in employment decisions affecting individuals.

### Conditions for Using an AEDT:

1. **Bias Audit Requirement**:
   - The AEDT must have undergone a **bias audit** conducted by an independent auditor within one year prior to its use. This audit assesses the tool's impact on various demographic categories (e.g., race, ethnicity, sex).

2. **Public Disclosure**:
   - A summary of the results from the most recent bias audit, along with the **distribution date** of the AEDT, must be publicly available on the employer's or employment agency's website before the tool is used.

3. **Notification to Candidates**:
   - Employers must notify candidates or employees who reside in the city about the use of the AEDT at least **ten business days** before its application. This notification should include:
     - Information that an AEDT will be used in the assessment.
     - The job qualifications and characteristics that the AEDT will evaluate.
     - If not disclosed on the website, details about the type of data used in the assessment.

4. **Impact Assessment**:
   - The bias audit must calculate selection rates and impact ratios for each demographic category required to be reported to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). This includes:
     - Separate calculations for sex categories.
     - Separate calculations for race/ethnicity categories.
     - Intersectional categories (e.g., combinations of sex and race/ethnicity).

5. **Exclusion of Certain Data**:
   - The bias audit must indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT who are not included in the calculations due to falling within an unknown category.

By adhering to these requirements, employers can ensure compliance with the regulations governing the use of AEDTs in New York City.
correctness_reason: The agent's definition of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) is mostly accurate, but it lacks the specific exclusion criteria mentioned in the ground truth, which states that it does not include tools that do not automate or materially impact natural persons. Additionally, the agent's answer is overly detailed regarding conditions for use, which is not part of the ground truth definition.

question: As an employer or employment agency in the city, what are the acceptable methods to provide notice to a candidate for employment about the use of an AEDT?
reference_answer: An employer or employment agency may provide notice to a candidate for employment by doing any of the following: (1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT, (2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT, or (3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT.
reference_context:
Document 21: Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT. 
(c) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to an employee being considered for promotion who resides in the city by doing any of the 
following: 
(1) Provide notice in a written policy or procedure that is provided to employees at least 10 
business days before use of an AEDT;

(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT.  
(d) To comply with § 20-871(b)(3) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must: 
(1) Provide information on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous 
manner about its AEDT data retention policy, the type of data collected for the AEDT, and the 
source of the data; 
(2) Post instructions on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
for how to make a written request for such information, and if a written request is received, 
provide such information within 30 days; and 
(3) Provide an explanation to a candidate for employment or employee being considered for

§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios

(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.  
(b) The requirements of subdivision (a) of this section may be met with an active hyperlink to a website 
containing the required summary of results and distribution date, provided that the link is clearly identified 
as a link to results of the bias audit. 
(c) An employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for 
at least 6 months after its latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.   
 
§ 5-304 Notice to Candidates and Employees.  
(a) The notice required by § 20-871(b)(1) of the Code must include instructions for how an individual can 
request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if 
available. Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide

at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT.

agent_answer:
As an employer or employment agency in the city, you can provide notice to a candidate for employment about the use of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) through the following acceptable methods:

1. **Website Notice**: Provide notice on the employment section of your website in a clear and conspicuous manner at least 10 business days before the use of the AEDT.

2. **Job Posting**: Include notice in the job posting at least 10 business days before the use of the AEDT.

3. **Direct Communication**: Send notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before the use of the AEDT. 

These methods ensure that candidates are adequately informed prior to the assessment or evaluation process.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

agent_answer:
A bias audit for automated employment decision tools (AEDTs) is an impartial evaluation conducted by an independent auditor to assess the potential discriminatory impact of these tools on various demographic groups. Here’s a breakdown of what a bias audit entails and its purpose:

### What a Bias Audit Entails:

1. **Evaluation of Selection Rates**: The audit calculates the selection rates for different demographic categories (e.g., sex, race/ethnicity) to determine how many candidates from each group are selected by the AEDT.

2. **Impact Ratio Calculation**: It compares the selection rates across different categories to compute an impact ratio. This ratio helps identify if certain groups are disproportionately favored or disadvantaged by the tool.

3. **Intersectional Analysis**: The audit may also analyze the impact on intersectional categories (e.g., Hispanic male candidates vs. Black female candidates) to understand how multiple factors may affect selection outcomes.

4. **Historical Data Review**: The auditor reviews historical data collected during the use of the AEDT to assess its performance and any biases that may have emerged over time.

5. **Reporting**: The results of the bias audit must be summarized and made publicly available, including the distribution date of the AEDT and any findings regarding its impact on different demographic groups.

### Why a Bias Audit is Required:

1. **Compliance with Regulations**: In New York City, it is unlawful for employers or employment agencies to use an AEDT for employment decisions unless it has undergone a bias audit within the past year. This requirement is part of local legislation aimed at promoting fairness in hiring practices.

2. **Mitigating Discrimination**: The primary purpose of a bias audit is to identify and mitigate any potential biases in the automated decision-making process. This helps ensure that employment decisions are made fairly and do not disproportionately disadvantage any particular group.

3. **Transparency and Accountability**: By requiring audits and public reporting of their results, the legislation promotes transparency in the use of AEDTs. This accountability helps build trust among candidates and employees regarding the fairness of the hiring process.

4. **Improving Decision-Making**: Conducting a bias audit can also provide insights into how the AEDT operates, allowing employers to make necessary adjustments to improve its fairness and effectiveness.

In summary, a bias audit is a critical tool for ensuring that automated employment decision tools are used responsibly and equitably, aligning with legal requirements and ethical hiring practices.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of what a bias audit entails and its general purpose, but it does not specifically address the legal requirements and components outlined in the ground truth answer regarding the reporting of disparate impact on specific demographic categories as per U.S. regulations.

question: I'm reviewing a policy document and came across the term 'Impact Ratio.' Can you explain what it means and how it is calculated?
reference_answer: The 'Impact Ratio' can be calculated as either the selection rate for a category divided by the selection rate of the most selected category, or the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the highest scoring category.
reference_context:
Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

agent_answer:
The term **Impact Ratio** refers to a metric used to assess the fairness and effectiveness of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) in the hiring or promotion process. It compares the selection or scoring rates of different categories (such as sex or race/ethnicity) to identify any potential biases.

### Calculation of Impact Ratio

The Impact Ratio can be calculated in two ways:

1. **Selection Rate Impact Ratio**:
   \[
   \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{\text{Selection Rate for a Category}}{\text{Selection Rate of the Most Selected Category}}
   \]

2. **Scoring Rate Impact Ratio**:
   \[
   \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{\text{Scoring Rate for a Category}}{\text{Scoring Rate of the Highest Scoring Category}}
   \]

### Definitions:
- **Selection Rate**: The rate at which individuals in a category are selected to move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by the AEDT.
- **Scoring Rate**: The rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above the sample’s median score, calculated by the AEDT.

### Example:
If the selection rate for male candidates is 60% and for female candidates is 45%, the Impact Ratio for females would be:
\[
\text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{45\%}{60\%} = 0.75
\]
This indicates that female candidates are selected at a rate that is 75% of the rate for male candidates.

The Impact Ratio helps organizations identify and address any disparities in their hiring processes, ensuring a more equitable approach.
correctness_reason: The agent's explanation of the Impact Ratio and its calculation methods aligns well with the ground truth answer.

data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers

employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available

question: I'm trying to understand the definition of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' according to the New York City Administrative Code. Can you explain what it means and provide examples of how it can be used?
reference_answer: An 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' or 'AEDT' is defined as a tool that substantially assists or replaces discretionary decision making by either relying solely on a simplified output, using a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where it is weighted more than any other criterion, or using a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including human decision-making.
reference_context:
Document 4: 1 
 
New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection 
 
Notice of Adoption of Final Rule 
 
Pursuant to the authority vested in the Commissioner of the Department of Consumer and Worker Protection by 
Sections 1043 and 2203(f) of the New York City Charter and Section 20-104(b) of the New York City 
Administrative Code, and in accordance with the requirements of Section 1043 of the New York City Charter, 
the Department amends Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York.  
 
An initial version of this rule was proposed and published on September 23, 2022. A public hearing was held on 
November 4, 2022, and comments regarding the rule were received. DCWP proposed a second version of this 
rule on December 23, 2022. A public hearing was held on January 23, 2023, and comments regarding the rule 
were received.  
 
Statement of Basis and Purpose 
 
The Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (“DCWP” or “Department”) is adding rules to implement 
new legislation regarding automated employment decision tools (“AEDT”). Local Law 144 of 2021 prohibits 
employers and employment agencies from using an automated employment decision tool unless the tool has 
been subject to a bias audit within one year of the use of the tool, information about the bias audit is publicly 
available, and certain notices have been provided to employees or job candidates.   
 
These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law.

Document 7: 3 
 
Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.  
 
Historical data.
metadata: {'question_type': 'complex_situational', 'seed_document_id': 4, 'topic': 'Requirements'}
agent_answer:
The term **"Automated Employment Decision Tool" (AEDT)**, as defined by the New York City Administrative Code, refers to any computational process that utilizes machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to produce simplified outputs—such as scores, classifications, or recommendations—that significantly assist or replace discretionary decision-making in employment contexts.

### Key Aspects of the Definition:
1. **Simplified Output**: The tool generates outputs like scores or classifications that are used in making employment decisions.
2. **Substantial Assistance or Replacement**: The tool either assists in or completely replaces human judgment in decision-making processes related to employment.
3. **Impact on Natural Persons**: The decisions made using the tool must affect real individuals (candidates or employees).

### Examples of Use:
1. **Resume Screening Software**: An AEDT might analyze resumes and assign scores based on keywords or qualifications, helping employers decide which candidates to interview.
  
2. **Interview Assessment Tools**: A tool could evaluate candidates' responses during video interviews using AI to assess their suitability based on predefined criteria.

3. **Employee Promotion Tools**: An AEDT might analyze employee performance data to recommend candidates for promotion based on their scores compared to others.

4. **Job Matching Platforms**: These platforms use algorithms to match candidates with job openings based on their skills and experiences, providing a ranking of the best fits.

### Important Considerations:
- **Bias Audits**: Before using an AEDT, employers must conduct a bias audit to ensure that the tool does not disproportionately disadvantage any group based on race, ethnicity, or sex.
- **Transparency**: Employers are required to disclose information about the AEDT, including the results of the bias audit and the criteria used for assessments, to candidates.

In summary, AEDTs are tools that leverage technology to streamline and enhance employment decision-making processes, but they come with responsibilities to ensure fairness and transparency.
correctness_reason: The agent's definition of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' is not fully aligned with the ground truth. While it captures some aspects, it lacks the specific details about how the tool can either rely solely on a simplified output, be weighted more than other criteria, or overrule human decision-making, which are key components of the definition.

agent_answer:
In the bias audit calculations, an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than **2%** of the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for the impact ratio.

### Example of a Category that Can Be Excluded:
Suppose an employer conducts a bias audit and finds that there are only **5 applicants** from the category "Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander," which represents **1.5%** of the total applicant pool. Since this category is less than 2%, it can be excluded from the calculations.

### Information to Include in the Summary of Results:
The summary of results must include:
- **Justification for the exclusion**: The independent auditor should explain why the category was excluded, citing that it represents less than 2% of the total data.
- **Number of applicants in the excluded category**: In this case, it would be **5 applicants**.
- **Scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded category**: For example, if the scoring rate for the "Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander" category was **62.5%**, this information should also be included.

This ensures transparency in the audit process and provides context for the exclusion.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides additional details and examples that are not part of the ground truth, which only states the minimum percentage for exclusion without elaboration.

question: What information about bias audits of an AEDT must be publicly available before its use?
reference_answer: Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make publicly available on their website the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. The summary should include the source and explanation of the data used for the bias audit, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT falling within an unknown category, and the number of applicants or candidates, selection or scoring rates, and impact ratios for all categories.
reference_context:
Document 19: 9 
 
Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of

data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of results of the 
bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was 
generated and obtained.

audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or employment agencies, or on a bias audit 
conducted using test data.

Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates).

for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and

agent_answer:
Before the use of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT), the following information about bias audits must be publicly available on the employment section of the employer or employment agency's website:

1. **Date of the Most Recent Bias Audit**: The date when the most recent bias audit was conducted.
2. **Summary of Results**: This summary must include:
   - The source and explanation of the data used for the bias audit.
   - The number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that fall within an unknown category.
   - The number of applicants or candidates, along with the selection or scoring rates, as applicable.
   - The impact ratios for all categories.
3. **Distribution Date of the AEDT**: The date when the AEDT was distributed.

Additionally, this information must be kept posted for at least six months after the latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision. Employers may also provide an active hyperlink to a website containing the required summary and distribution date, as long as the link is clearly identified.

reference_answer: The term 'Bias Audit' is defined as 'Bias audit' as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.

agent_answer:
In the context of New York City's regulations on Automated Employment Decision Tools (AEDTs), a **Bias Audit** is defined as an impartial evaluation conducted by an **independent auditor**. The purpose of the audit is to assess the AEDT's impact on various demographic groups, specifically looking for any disparate impact on candidates based on race, ethnicity, and sex categories as required by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC).

### Key Aspects of a Bias Audit:
1. **Impartial Evaluation**: The audit must be objective and free from any conflicts of interest.
2. **Independent Auditor**: The auditor must not have any prior involvement in the development, use, or distribution of the AEDT. They should also not have any employment relationship with the employer or employment agency using the AEDT.
3. **Assessment of Disparate Impact**: The audit includes testing the AEDT to determine if it disproportionately affects candidates from specific demographic groups.
4. **Reporting**: The results of the bias audit must be summarized and made publicly available, including the distribution date of the AEDT.

### Who Can Conduct a Bias Audit?
An **independent auditor** is the only entity allowed to conduct a bias audit. This auditor must possess the capability to exercise objective and impartial judgment regarding the AEDT being evaluated. They cannot have any financial interest or employment relationship with the employer or agency using the AEDT or with the vendor that developed it.

In summary, a Bias Audit is a critical component of ensuring that AEDTs are used fairly and do not perpetuate discrimination in employment decisions.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of a Bias Audit but does not reference the specific definition from § 20-870 of the Code, which is the expected ground truth.

question: Before using an AEDT, what information must an employer or employment agency make publicly available on their website?
reference_answer: Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make publicly available on their website the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT, a summary of the results including the source and explanation of the data used, the number of individuals assessed, the number of applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, and the impact ratios for all categories. They must also provide the distribution date of the AEDT.

question: I am an employer planning to use an AEDT for screening resumes and scheduling interviews. Can you explain the requirements for conducting a bias audit of the AEDT, including the calculation of impact ratio for different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories?
reference_answer: A bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category required to be reported to the EEOC, and compare the selection rates to determine an impact ratio. The audit must also separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race. Additionally, the audit must indicate the number of individuals not included in the calculations due to falling within an unknown category.

metadata: {'question_type': 'complex_situational', 'seed_document_id': 6, 'topic': 'Definitions'}
agent_answer:
As an employer planning to use an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) for screening resumes and scheduling interviews, you must adhere to specific requirements for conducting a bias audit. Here’s a breakdown of the key requirements:

### 1. **Timing of the Bias Audit**
- **Conduct a Bias Audit**: You must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT has been conducted no more than one year prior to its use. This is mandatory even if the AEDT is only used for initial screening and not for final hiring decisions.

### 2. **Calculations Required in the Bias Audit**
The bias audit must include the following calculations:

#### a. **Selection Rate Calculation**
- Calculate the selection rate for each category (e.g., sex, race/ethnicity) that is required to be reported to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC).

#### b. **Impact Ratio Calculation**
- Calculate the impact ratio for each category. This involves comparing the selection rates of different groups to the most selected category. The impact ratio is calculated as follows:
  \[
  \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{\text{Selection Rate of Group}}{\text{Selection Rate of Most Selected Group}}
  \]

#### c. **Categories to Consider**
- **Sex Categories**: Calculate the impact ratio for male vs. female candidates.
- **Race/Ethnicity Categories**: Calculate the impact ratio for different racial/ethnic groups (e.g., Hispanic or Latino vs. Black or African American).
- **Intersectional Categories**: Calculate the impact ratio for combinations of sex and race/ethnicity (e.g., Hispanic or Latino male vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American female).

### 3. **Additional Requirements**
- **Group Classification**: If the AEDT classifies candidates into specific groups (e.g., leadership styles), ensure that the calculations are performed for each group.
- **Unknown Categories**: Indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT who fall into an unknown category and are not included in the calculations.

### 4. **Public Availability of Results**
- The results of the bias audit, including the selection rates and impact ratios, must be made publicly available on your website before using the AEDT.

### 5. **Independent Auditor**
- The bias audit should be conducted by an independent auditor who has no financial interest in your organization or the AEDT vendor.

### Example Calculation
For instance, if you have the following data for sex categories:
- **Male**: 1390 applicants, 667 selected (Selection Rate = 48%)
- **Female**: 1181 applicants, 555 selected (Selection Rate = 47%)

The impact ratio would be calculated as:
- For Males: \( \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{48\%}{48\%} = 1.00 \)
- For Females: \( \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{47\%}{48\%} \approx 0.979 \)

This process ensures that the AEDT does not disproportionately impact any particular group and complies with the legal requirements set forth in the regulations.

applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

Document 18: (a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of results of the 
bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was 
generated and obtained.  
 
Example 1: An employer is planning to use an AEDT for the first time. The employer may rely on a bias 
audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or employment agencies, or on a bias audit 
conducted using test data.

Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

agent_answer: If you have been using an AEDT for 6 months, your own historical data is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. You will need to rely on a bias audit that uses historical data from other employers or employment agencies. However, you can provide your 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for consideration alongside the historical data from other sources. Alternatively, you may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data if there is insufficient historical data available.

It must also indicate the number of individuals not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category.

agent_answer:
When using an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) for hiring, compliance with bias audit requirements is essential. Here’s a breakdown of the key requirements for conducting a bias audit, particularly focusing on the calculation of impact ratios for different race/ethnicity and sex categories:

### Requirements for a Bias Audit

1. **Timing of the Audit**:
   - An employer or employment agency cannot use an AEDT if more than one year has passed since the most recent bias audit.

2. **Minimum Calculations**:
   The bias audit must include the following calculations:
   - **Selection Rate**: Calculate the selection rate for each category (e.g., male, female, different racial/ethnic groups).
   - **Impact Ratio**: Calculate the impact ratio for each category, which compares the selection rates of different groups.

3. **Categories for Impact Ratios**:
   The impact ratios must be calculated separately for:
   - **Sex Categories**: For example, compare the selection rates of male candidates versus female candidates.
   - **Race/Ethnicity Categories**: For example, compare the selection rates of Hispanic or Latino candidates versus Black or African American candidates.
   - **Intersectional Categories**: This includes combinations of sex, ethnicity, and race. For example, compare the selection rates of Hispanic or Latino male candidates versus Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American female candidates.

4. **Exclusion of Small Categories**:
   - An independent auditor may exclude any category that represents less than 2% of the data from the calculations. If a category is excluded, the auditor must provide justification and include the number of applicants and their scoring or selection rates for that excluded category in the summary of results.

5. **Reporting Requirements**:
   - The results of the bias audit, including the number of individuals assessed that fall within an unknown category, must be publicly available on the employer's website. This includes:
     - The date of the most recent bias audit.
     - A summary of the results, including the source and explanation of the data used, the number of applicants, selection rates, and impact ratios for all categories.

### Example of Impact Ratio Calculation

For instance, if you have the following data:

**Sex Categories**:
- Male: 1390 applicants, 667 selected (Selection Rate: 48%)
- Female: 1181 applicants, 555 selected (Selection Rate: 47%)

**Impact Ratio Calculation**:
- Male Impact Ratio: 1.00 (as the baseline)
- Female Impact Ratio: 0.979 (47% / 48%)

**Race/Ethnicity Categories**:
- Hispanic or Latino: 28 applicants, 18 selected (Selection Rate: 64.2%)
- Black or African American: 32 applicants, 16 selected (Selection Rate: 50.0%)

**Impact Ratio Calculation**:
- Hispanic or Latino Impact Ratio: 1.00 (baseline)
- Black or African American Impact Ratio: 0.78 (50% / 64.2%)

### Conclusion

To ensure compliance when using an AEDT, it is crucial to conduct a thorough bias audit that includes the necessary calculations and reporting. Regular audits and transparency in the results will help mitigate bias and promote fair hiring practices.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer accurately explains the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT, including the calculation of selection rates and impact ratios for different categories, as well as the reporting requirements related to individuals in unknown categories.

metadata: {'question_type': 'complex_situational', 'seed_document_id': 5, 'topic': 'Metrics/Data'}
agent_answer:
To conduct a bias audit for an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) and calculate the impact ratio for different race/ethnicity and sex categories, you must follow these specific requirements:

1. **Calculate Selection Rates**:
   - Determine the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category. The selection rate is calculated by dividing the number of individuals selected by the total number of individuals in that category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.

2. **Calculate Impact Ratios**:
   - The impact ratio for each category is calculated by comparing the selection rate of that category to the selection rate of the most selected category. The formula is:
     \[
     \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{\text{Selection Rate for a Category}}{\text{Selection Rate of the Most Selected Category}}
     \]

3. **Separate Calculations**:
   - Ensure that the calculations are performed separately for:
     - **Sex Categories**: Compare the impact ratio for male candidates vs. female candidates.
     - **Race/Ethnicity Categories**: For example, compare the impact ratio for Hispanic or Latino candidates vs. Black or African American candidates.
     - **Intersectional Categories**: Calculate the impact ratio for combinations of sex and race/ethnicity, such as Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American female candidates.

4. **Include Unknown Categories**:
   - Indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that are not included in the required calculations because they fall within an unknown category.

5. **Exclusion of Small Categories**:
   - An independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. If a category is excluded, the auditor must provide justification for the exclusion and include the number of applicants and their scoring or selection rates for that excluded category.

By following these requirements, you can ensure that your bias audit is comprehensive and compliant with the established guidelines.

question: I'm reviewing a policy document and came across the term 'Impact Ratio'. Can you explain what it means and how it is calculated?
reference_answer: The 'Impact Ratio' can be calculated by either dividing the selection rate for a category by the selection rate of the most selected category, or dividing the scoring rate for a category by the scoring rate for the highest scoring category.
reference_context:
Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

at any point during the bias audit, has a direct financial interest or a material indirect

rate of the most selected category or (2) the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the 
highest scoring category.

based techniques:  
i. 
that generate a prediction, meaning an expected outcome for an observation, such as an

meaning an assignment of an observation to a group, such as categorizations based on 
skill sets or aptitude; and

for which a computer at least in part identifies the inputs, the relative importance placed

by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.

agent_answer:
The term **Impact Ratio** refers to a metric used to assess the fairness and effectiveness of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) in the hiring or promotion process. It helps to evaluate whether different demographic groups are being treated equitably.

### Definition:
The Impact Ratio can be calculated in two ways:

1. **Selection Rate Impact Ratio**:
   \[
   \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{\text{Selection Rate for a Category}}{\text{Selection Rate of the Most Selected Category}}
   \]

2. **Scoring Rate Impact Ratio**:
   \[
   \text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{\text{Scoring Rate for a Category}}{\text{Scoring Rate of the Highest Scoring Category}}
   \]

### Explanation of Terms:
- **Selection Rate**: The rate at which individuals in a specific category (e.g., gender, race) are selected to move forward in the hiring process.
- **Scoring Rate**: The rate at which individuals in a specific category receive a score above the sample's median score, as calculated by the AEDT.

### Example Calculation:
If you have the following data:
- For **Hispanic women**: 40 out of 100 applicants selected (Selection Rate = 40%)
- For **White men**: 80 out of 100 applicants selected (Selection Rate = 80%)

The Impact Ratio for Hispanic women would be:
\[
\text{Impact Ratio} = \frac{40\%}{80\%} = 0.50
\]

This indicates that Hispanic women are selected at half the rate of White men.

### Purpose:
The Impact Ratio is crucial for conducting bias audits to ensure that the AEDT does not disproportionately disadvantage any demographic group in the hiring or promotion process.

question: I want to conduct a bias audit for an AEDT. What are the requirements for calculating the impact ratio for sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories? Are there any criteria for excluding certain categories from the calculations?
reference_answer: A bias audit of an AEDT must, at a minimum, calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race, perform the calculations for each group if the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups, and indicate the number of individuals not included in the calculations due to falling within an unknown category.

§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.
